title: Lungs Data - EDA and Data Visualization in R
description: Explored and visualized lungs data in R, performing EDA to uncover patterns and trends. Utilized R packages for effective data visualization, providing insights into respiratory health indicators.
contents:
Setup Chunks in RMarkdown
Loading Required Libraries
Loading several essential libraries, including “tidyverse”, “highcharter”. These libraries offer diverse functionalities for data manipulation, visualization, and reporting.
And also we need the “survival” package for the NCCTG Lung Cancer data set in it.
and to save the cleaned data to the directory we need “openxlsx” package



Data Description
NCCTG Lung Cancer Data
Survival in patients with advanced lung cancer from the North Central Cancer Treatment Group. Performance scores rate how well the patient can perform usual daily activities.
Format
inst: Institution code.
time: Survival time in days.
status: censoring status 1=censored, 2=dead.
age: Age in years.
sex: Male=1 Female=2.
ph.ecog: ECOG performance score as rated by the physician. 0=asymptomatic, 1= symptomatic but completely ambulatory, 2= in bed <50% of the day, 3= in bed > 50% of the day but not bedbound, 4 = bedbound.
ph.karno: Karnofsky performance score (bad=0-good=100) rated by physician.
pat.karno: Karnofsky performance score as rated by patient.
meal.cal: Calories consumed at meals.
wt.loss: Weight loss in last six months (pounds).

Dimensions
The dataset consists of 228 rows and 10 columns.

[1] 228  10

Names in the dataset
The names of the columns in the dataset are:

 [1] "inst"      "time"      "status"    "age"       "sex"      
 [6] "ph.ecog"   "ph.karno"  "pat.karno" "meal.cal"  "wt.loss"  

Data Types
The data types of the columns are as follows:

     inst      time    status       age       sex   ph.ecog  ph.karno 
 "double"  "double"  "double"  "double"  "double"  "double"  "double" 
pat.karno  meal.cal   wt.loss 
 "double"  "double"  "double" 

Data Summary
A summary of the dataset provides descriptive statistics for numerical variables, including measures such as mean, median, minimum, maximum, and quartiles. For categorical variables, it displays their class, length, and mode. This overview helps understand the central tendencies and distributions of numerical data, as well as the characteristics of categorical variables.

title: My Journey into the World of Biostatistics
description: A journey fueled by curiosity, transforming my passion for data into a career in biostatistics, where I analyze complex health data to drive impactful, evidence-based decisions in public health.
contents:
Welcome to My Biostatistics Journey
Hello and welcome to my corner of the digital world! I’m thrilled to have you here.
As an aspiring Biostatistician, I’m on a mission to transform complex data into actionable insights that can make a real difference in healthcare and biological research. This blog is where I’ll share my journey, discoveries, and thoughts on the fascinating intersection of statistics and health.
What You’ll Find Here
Insights from my latest data analysis projects
Explorations of statistical methods in healthcare
Reflections on my academic and professional experiences
Tips and tutorials on tools like R, R Shiny, R Packages, SQL, and Python
Discussions on the latest trends in biostatistics and public health
A Bit About Me
I hold a Master’s degree in Statistics and have a passion for using data to solve real-world problems. From analyzing Complete Blood Count datasets to developing predictive models for fertility outcomes in PCOS patients, I’m always eager to dive into complex healthcare data.
When I’m not crunching numbers, you might find me creating interactive Shiny apps, volunteering for community surveys, or exploring new ways to visualize data.
Let’s Connect
I believe in the power of collaboration and community. Whether you’re a fellow data enthusiast, a healthcare professional, or simply curious about the world of biostatistics, I’d love to hear from you. Feel free to reach out with questions, ideas, or opportunities to collaborate.
Thank you for stopping by. I hope you’ll join me on this exciting journey of discovery and innovation in biostatistics!
Stay curious and keep analyzing,
Prasanth Kumar.
